image.altText: A microphone standing in a court room with a blurred coat of arms in the background.

props.synopsis: A coronial inquest examining the death of a Tiwi Islands woman in a secure mental health ward has revealed "multiple failings" reduced the quality of her care.

title.children: 'It should never have happened': NT Health apologises for death of patient

image.altText: Houses on a hill.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank estimates around 5 per cent of mortgage borrowers are spending more on their repayments and essential living expenses than they earn, and more than 2 per cent could run out of savings by the end of next year.

title.children: Australia's banks safe even as up to 100,000 borrowers risk running out of cash, RBA review finds

image.altText: Mitch East smiling wearing a navy suit and white shirt against a white background

props.synopsis: A 63-year-old man is charged with a number of offences after lawyer Mitch East died in an alleged hit and run in Sydney's eastern suburbs on Sunday morning.

title.children: Man charged over alleged hit and run which killed Sydney lawyer Mitch East

image.altText: Borroloola residents on board a Hercules aircraft at Borroloola airport.

props.synopsis: Three more evacuation flights out of the inundated town of Borroloola are scheduled for Thursday afternoon after more than 100 people were airlifted from the remote community overnight in the wake of heavy rains associated with ex-Tropical Cyclone Megan.

title.children: ADF continues evacuations of Borroloola residents as McArthur River nears record flood peak

image.altText: Solar farm in southern Queensland with glowing sunset.

props.synopsis: Entrepreneur Dick Smith says no country has ever been able to run on renewables, labelling the idea "impossible". What do they experts say?

title.children: We fact checked Dick Smith on whether a country can run entirely on renewables. Here's what we found

image.altText: A woman smiling with sungalsses in front of the harbour bridge

props.synopsis: Our neighbours across the ditch have been bumped down to number 11 in the Global Happiness Report, but is Australia really happier?

title.children: Australia has outranked New Zealand for happiness. But why?

image.altText: A graphic of keli Lane wearing a jacket with barbed wires behind her and a building

props.synopsis: The judge on Keli Lane's trial has since said her case was "circumstantial", but the State Parole Authority denied her parole quoting the 'no body, no parole' laws.

title.children: Convicted baby killer Keli Lane to remain in jail under NSW's 'no body, no parole' laws

image.altText: A quiet street in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

props.synopsis: Property analysis firm CoreLogic says that despite extraordinary property market price gains in recent years, demand remains robust.

title.children: 'I don't think it's a Ponzi scheme,' leading economist says, as Australia's median property value rises by $63,000 in a year

image.altText: Man wearing headphones in ABC radio studio sitting in front of microphone.

props.synopsis: The ABC Radio Sydney presenter says he's received an "overwhelming" response from listeners following yesterday's candid and characteristically humorous show, and "not to be too macabre, but … the eulogies have been very nice".

title.children: James Valentine buoyed by 'cloud of support and affection' after sharing news of cancer diagnosis

image.altText: a male politician wearing a suit and tie with an indigenous print

props.synopsis: Country Liberal Party Member for Barkly Steve Edgington has resigned as shadow minister for the prevention of domestic, family and sexual violence.

title.children: Steve Edgington resigns as NT's shadow DV minister following reports of business ties, staffer suspension

image.altText: The tailings storage facility, also known as water dam, at ERA's Ranger Uranium Mine.

props.synopsis: Mining company ERA wants to extend its lease on Jabiluka — one of the world's largest uranium deposits — but Mirarr traditional owners are fiercely opposed to the plan.

title.children: Company applies to extend NT uranium mine lease against traditional owners' request

image.altText: a man holding a surfboard coming out of the surf

props.synopsis: Grant Coleman has been jailed for a one-punch attack that killed former pro-surfer Chris Davidson outside a NSW club.

title.children: One-punch attacker jailed for fatal assault on former pro-surfer

image.altText: The back of a young boy's head, looking toward a teacher at the front of a classroom.

props.synopsis: School principals suffer the worst levels of physical violence, threats and bullying in the history of a long-running national survey.

title.children: Disturbing increase in violence at school as principals say both parents and students are making threats

image.altText: A young smiling woman embraces a young man, whose back is to the camera. Another smiling woman is visible in the background.

props.synopsis: Hosting is second nature to some and sweat-inducing for others, but etiquette experts Julie Lamberg-Burnet and Amanda King have tips to help guide you through the Easter long weekend.

title.children: Advice for the uneasy host (or house guest) this Easter

image.altText: Beau Lamarre in a police uniform

props.synopsis: The police officer who allegedly murdered Sydney couple Jesse Baird and Luke Davies has been removed from the police force by the NSW Commissioner.

title.children: Officer accused of murdering Sydney couple removed from police force

image.altText: Two men in suits outside of a court house

props.synopsis: Prosecutors are seeking jail time for Thomas Sewell and Jacob Hersant, who were among 25 men who attacked six hikers in 2021.

title.children: Prosecutors seek jail over 'terrifying' neo-Nazi attack on Victorian hikers

image.altText: ambulance and man holding fish

props.synopsis: Damien Woods and his cousin were able to get back onto a flat rock after being swept out during a dangerous swell but another wave then washed them back in the water.

title.children: Inquest hears West Australian teen probably drowned shortly after south coast rock fishing tragedy

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Donald Trump's jab, a miracle platypus, and another royal controversy

image.altText: A group of people stand in the valley floor surrounded by mountains

props.synopsis: It was supposed to be an adventurous day-trip deep into New Zealand's rugged Southern Alps, but on February 12, 1962, the tourists on board the Dragonfly never came home.

title.children: This rugged coastline is the site of mysterious crashes. One expert calls it 'New Zealand's Bermuda Triangle'

image.altText: Geraldton court

props.synopsis: A Geraldton magistrate expresses his frustration after learning a 13-year-old West Australian boy accused of burglary and stealing was left to live alone for a fortnight.

title.children: 'Did you eat yesterday?': Teenager's admission of neglect stuns regional magistrate

image.altText: A Woolworths trolley filled with toliet paper, instant coffee, tampons, milk, eggs, bread and Weetbix.

props.synopsis: Food prices and overall inflation will rise as temperatures climb with climate change, a new study by an environmental scientist and the European Central Bank finds.

title.children: 'Climateflation' tipped to drive up food prices, new study finds

image.altText: three photos of a young woman side-by-side, in each one she is wearing linen pants with different tops and shoes

props.synopsis: How many items of clothing do you own, and how often do you wear them? Experts want shoppers to use this knowledge — along with upcycling the "skinny pile" and pressing pause on new buys — to fight the fashion churn destroying the planet.

title.children: Could you survive a 'wardrobe freeze' for a year? Keen to quit fast fashion, this stylist took on the challenge

image.altText: A woman with her mouth scribbled out and eyes blurred.

props.synopsis: Sophie* came to Australia to pursue a PhD but when her relationship turned violent she felt like she had nowhere to go.

title.children: Being in a foreign country, Sophie didn't know where to go when she left her violent relationship

image.altText: Jane Hume in a white suit at a press conference.

props.synopsis: A new national women's Liberal network quietly launches to a small crowd at Parliament House, more than a year after it was recommended by a party review of the 2022 election loss.

title.children: Ex-Ted Cruz spokesman and Peta Credlin to help Liberal Party's newly launched network to recruit women

image.altText: Logging, firearm, salmon composite image.

props.synopsis: No matter who wins this weekend's Tasmanian state election, it'll be more of the same in many ways. Here are some key policies where it is hard to tell the Liberals and Labor apart.

title.children: No matter which major party forms government in Tasmania, there are some things they've both promised

image.altText: Group of protesters with placards

props.synopsis: A rescue package promised earlier this year has failed to materialise for one of Australia's oldest sugar mills that will close in Far North Queensland.

title.children: Sugar mill closure leaves 150 workers without jobs after buy-out falls through

image.altText: Rainbow flag

props.synopsis: Advocacy group Equality Australia calls the move a "historic step", paying tribute to trailblazing 78ers who took to the streets in protest to make change for the LGBTQ+ community.

title.children: 'We will protect you': NSW bans gay conversion therapy after marathon parliamentary debate

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walks out of a church after a Good Friday service.

props.synopsis: An independent review into protecting LGBT staff and students at religious schools is now complete, but the government's own plans are no clearer.

title.children: PM says religious schools reform 'should be possible', but plans are unclear

props.synopsis: There were definitely no muppets 270 million years ago, but there was a Kermit — or at least an ancestor of modern amphibians, according to scientists who uncovered its fossilised skull.

title.children: Meet Kermitops, the newly discovered prehistoric creature named after Kermit the Frog

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market closed down on Friday, even as Wall Street's main indices set fresh records, and Reddit debuted on the market with a massive share price jump. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Banks and energy drag ASX lower, despite Wall Street's fresh records overnight

image.altText: Woman in rubble

props.synopsis: The largest missile attack in weeks injured at least 17 and damaged schools, homes and industrial facilities.

title.children: Dozens injured as Russia launches largest missile attack on Kyiv in weeks

image.altText: The silhouette of buildings are pictured with smoke rising above it.

props.synopsis: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says he believes talks in Qatar can still reach a Gaza ceasefire agreement, while Israel says it has attacked Hamas gunmen in the enclave's Al-Shifa hospital and evacuated patients.

title.children: Famine looms in Gaza as US secretary of state says ceasefire deal still possible

image.altText: Hillcrest Primary School in Devonport

props.synopsis: The castle's operator pleads not guilty to a failure to comply with health and safety duty, and is granted a request for a geotechnical engineer and an inflatables expert examine the castle and the school oval.

title.children: Hillcrest jumping castle to be examined by experts as court tentatively sets trial for September

image.altText: A submarine moves through calm waters

props.synopsis: Almost $5 billion will go to British industry in the next decade to help design and build key parts of Australia's future nuclear-powered submarine fleet that will be constructed in Adelaide.

title.children: China threat justifies AUKUS spend, UK says, as Australia unveils $5b package for British industry
